comments.commentBody:
But that's exactly what Mr.Sanders article is all about - Mrs. Clinton and her followers, and the DNC are not listening to the facts!

If the DNC and Hillary continue to rely on the "same old, same old", the part and her may be in for a very tight race for the presidency!

And the alternative is ever so more even more catastrophic!
Thank you!  And now maybe the Clintonites can get on board?

Look up HRCs record on fighting for childrens rights, for foster children, and poor children without health care over her career. Actually look what she accomplished for children. Don't just read slogans, look at her record. Then look at what Sanders has ever accomplished for children. And there you will find your answer of who really cares about "the people".
If he genuinely cared about people, he would have done more to help them during his 30 years in Congress other than renaming two post offices.

I heard Senator Sanders speak in Albany, NY this past Friday. This was the second time I've heard him speak, the first being at a massive rally at UMass, Amherst in February.

What impresses me about the senator is that he genuinely cares about people who have been left out of the political, economic, and social system and his campaign policy positions reflect that concern. This is the same concern that he expresses here.

Millions of people, and especially children, cannot be relegated to second-class citizenship because of forces often beyond their control. Just as the New Deal and Great Society attempted to address the needs of people, the political system needs to even the so-called playing field so that the basic needs of housing, healthcare, education, and freedom from want are central in this political and economic system once again.
I don't think that's entirely true. Germany deployed 3 times the amount of robots as the US and only lost 19% of it's manufacturing force, while the US lost of 30%.

I'm a Democrat who is certainly no fan of Donald Trump, but...at least he's addressing the issue.  What's Hillary proposing to slow the massive transfer of wealth from the American middle class to its Chinese counterpart?

And those coal miners in West Virginia and out of work steel workers to in Pennsylvania  know that? No. The know not muchers don't care if Trump is lying to them because they love his lack of PC rhetoric.

You have no idea what you are talking about. There is a cap of 20,000 immigrant visa per country per year - excluding immediate relatives of US citizens who are not subject to this quota - which is why the waiting list for a green card under EB-2 and EB-3 can be as long as 12 years.
It "came to this" because people like you have chosen to embrace self-imposed ignorance, as evidenced by your comment here.

Let this be a lesson to all major multinational corporations. Your fiduciary responsibility to your shareholders can only be maintained by not misleading your customers and fraudulently skirting regulations. Those regulations are in place to protect your customers and the public at large.

This scandal was born of short term profits. It costs many, many millions to develop a new engine. No question about that. Those new engines will in turn be used in millions of cars. The scope and scale of this malfeasance is mind boggling. And for what?

The engine could not meet specs. Its production should have been stopped and the problems worked out. That delay would also no doubt have cost many millions, perhaps many tens of millions or even much more. But they tried to pull a sneaky and got caught. Now they are on the hook for over $15 billion and that is just in America.

Remember the BP oil spill? That occurred because the bore was not completely filled with concrete. Only three plugs were poured in order to save money. How much was saved? $1 million? BP ended up spending tens of billions for mess.

Some people just can't learn from the mistakes of others. Volkswagen is now some people. Think about this the next time a corporate titian claims success in business is a qualification to hold high office. (Success often means I didn't get caught).

But if you increase tariffs, the cost of living will increase. And it cost more to hire a worker here so companies will just make do with fewer workers if that's their only option and invest more in replacing their jobs with robots.

So...essentially these tariffs will cause jobs to go away faster, fewer workers to be employed, and the real value of money to go down....

@jacob Lomg:

Precisely what many economists including Dr. Paul Krugman have said. A trade war is the last thing do United States needs during a very fledgling economy. His proposals could really do us in, with the aftershocks lasting for years.

We are a big market. Other countries are always going to want to trade with us. If we  equalize the playing field it could help our country. What is wrong with looking out for our country and out workers. What is wrong with giving them an advantage for a change? Let's make trade more favorable for this country!

The world’s economy is in such a bad shape that even the best minds in mainstream economics fail to give any clue to the politicians. Politicians of course love to speak on the subject because the urgent economical problem is what matters the most to everybody. With respect to the issue, a common-sense view is helpful, i.e. to vote for a wanna-be-billionaire like Hillary Clinton is not that much useful as a ready-made one like Donald Trump by reason of his bravura faith on the future of capital.

Globalization of capital has long been a herald of manna from heaven for the rich to raise their bottom lines. It may have also been some crumbs studded under the table for the gainfully employed middle class to scrounge around. It has not been so kind to the unemployed and underemployed or the working poor. Capital is defiantly doubling down on whoever wants to question globalization as people suddenly wake up to the gravity of the situation of the trade issue to which they have faced up.

Whoever wins the presidency will lead us nowhere economically so long as the system remains unchanged as the rootedness of the problem lies in the system of economy that strands in contradiction between socialized production and private expropriation of its means of production. Donald Trump might shock and awe the system to such a degree that it would start to rift a little. Only being reeling from entrenched problems of systemic failure, it would be able to repair its mistakes and reborn.
When your selling, you say what the buyer wants to hear.  Exactly :)
Lee, RSS uses the moniker north polar, last time I looked several months ago it read 10 years and 6 months without any warming, re the TLT, with other areas of the globe much longer,
There has to be movement by both Hillary Clinton and the DNC on one side, and by Bernie Sanders on the other side. That's what makes for an agreement - both sides move cooer to the middle.
George bush 1  initiated nafta. Deals were madeand Clinton had to abide
I can only recall two of the three. That either makes me younger or so old I've forgotten.
The proponents of Leave have absolutely no idea what to do next.

What do you think globalism is? Do you think it's another word for immigration. Well it's not. It is the reality that goods can be made where it's cheapest to make them and sold wherever people want the goods for purchase.
Do you only buy goods made in the US. If not, you are participating in the global economy. Do you want to pay 45% more for goods made in China and sold at your Walmart or Home Depot? Well that's the tariff rate Trump wants to slap on Chinese goods. And no president can change the movement of goods world wide. No Congress can change this. The only people who could change this sit on American company boards of directors. And they can't change it much.

Saint Ronnie Reagan happened.

He said government is the problem, so the (R)s made it their business to starve anything that smacks of government.

Since we do not have private companies offering to build subways, airports, water delivery systems, and similar "socialist" edifices, the starving of the government makes it difficult to have first class infrastructure.

You get exactly what you pay for. Don't pay, don't expect much in the way of infrastructure.
@bozicek: according to you, the country founded by the Englishmen and other Northern Europeans are losing out to the Chinese. Apparently the race you consider superior isn't so superior after all.
Hillary was for the TPP (the "Gold Standard" in trade deals) before she was against it. Just like Bill Clinton signed NAFTA into law, while she stood there smiling. Wall Street owns her.
We all know he is right. We all also know he will blow this country up.

I hate it when The Donald is right. Never mind the tariffs, the TPP gives corporations rights that overrule those of sovereign nations. It is Obama's gift to his corporate backers--especially Big Pharma and the information/entertainment conglomerates like Disney, who can sue for "potential lost profits" caused by national legislation.

comments.userLocation: Fair Verona where we lay our scene
comments.commentBody:
As IF it would ever matter to his followers.
But then, Hilary's troops would never miss a beat were she to baldly contradict herself either, would they?
The undecideds in this race will have the toughest choice ever - two people that no one would have chosen a generation ago.
Don't worry campers, he'll contradict himself as fast as one can say, roll the dice.

We spend less on public goods and services than a lot of countries do. It takes tax money to maintain good public transportation services, etc. Republicans always want to cut taxes and block spending on things like that. You get what you pay for.

And then slowly ebbs away because trade including our exports have no place to go. A vote for Trump is a vote for massive unemployment, a plummeting stock market and a wipe out of IRAs. Trump is a bankrupt hoping the U.S. populace will bail him out.
So, the fact that Trump represents the worst aspects of U.S business (and knows how to lie) means that he would make a good President?
In America, using public transport is considered declasse.

I thought that the DNC was a more open-minded party. When the DNC convention will occur, don't delegates make speeches from their points-of-view?

Or do they kowtow to the platform of the selected nominee without an ear to what others are saying?
